answers.answer: From: http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/elevated-liver-enzymes/HQ01011"A laboratory report of elevated liver enzymes is common and doesn't indicate a specific disease. However, elevated liver enzymes may be due to liver disease even if you have no symptoms. To determine the underlying cause of elevated liver enzymes, your doctor may recommend further testing.Common causes of elevated liver enzymes include:* Side effect of medication, such as certain nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), cholesterol medications, antibiotics or anti-seizure medications* Drinking alcohol* Obesity* Diabetes* Elevated triglycerides* Infection, such as viral hepatitis and mononucleosis* Autoimmune disorders of the liver and bile ducts, such as autoimmune hepatitis, primary sclerosing cholangitis or primary biliary cirrhosis* Metabolic liver disease, such as hemochromatosis or Wilson's disease* Excessive use of certain herbal supplements, such as kava, comfrey, pennyroyal or skullcap* Gallstones* Tumors of the liver, pancreas or bile ductsTreatment of elevated liver enzymes depends on its cause. It is important to tell your doctor about any nutritional or herbal supplements you're taking."Obesity is associated with fatty liver and I think that could be something to consider. One of the cornerstones of treating fatty liver is weight loss.Mike

question: Hi.. i did my blood work .. and it came withALT SGPT value of 100and AST SGOT value of 39i am a 32 yr old male... with a stage 1 obessity profile (Body Mass index of 30)I am Hep b and C negative...what could be the causes of this high level of hepatic enzymes in the serum ?
title: High Levels of ALT SGPT in Hep B & C negative male
